_source.text: 100 is nice for early-stage testing since the self-test will complete in roughly 1/10th the time, but 1000 is better once you have a good idea of optimal thread count on your system, because it yields a more-precise timing and is better at catching radix sets which may yield an unsafely high level of roundoff error for exponents near the upper limit of what the code allows for a given FFT length.

text: , but 1000 **is** **better** once you have a good idea of optimal thread count on your system, **because** it
yields a more-precise timing and **is** **better** at catching radix sets which may yield an unsafely **high** level
100 is nice for early-stage testing since the self-test will complete in roughly 1/10th the **time**
of roundoff error for exponents near the upper limit of what the code allows for a given FFT **length**.
